    Do-Hyeon Lee

    Interdisciplinary Mind-Behavior-Brain Scientist-Engineer

    Research Description

    First, my research focuses on theoretical algorithm and device design for human-level intelligent machines. These designs are based on insights from neuroscience, psychology, and cognitive science, derived from organisms that have successfully survived with limited resources such as time and energy. Primarily, I am interested in proposing AI models and computing devices that mimic human mechanisms of attention and decision-making. This exploration seeks to uncover the potential for energy-efficient and rapid intelligent algorithms. Furthermore, I am deeply interested in how symbolic systems like language and mathematics emerge from sub-symbolic systems such as neural networks. This includes proposing responsible language models and discovering new methods to evaluate AI model stability. Lastly, I propose AI models inspired by evolutionary psychology, challenging the traditional Tabula Rasa paradigm and emphasizing the importance of biological complexity in the learning process.

    Additionally, I am dedicated to developing a unified framework for the mind-behavior-brain connection. This involves analyzing principles such as the free energy principle, inductive bias principle, and data compression principle. This approach plays a crucial role in incorporating previously unexplained phenomena into the scientific domain. For example, to investigate consciousness, I formalize and compare existing theories like the global neural workspace theory, attention schema theory, and predictive coding theory. Through these comparisons, I propose new theories and plan more extensive research by implementing simulations. Furthermore, to explore hypnosis, I analyze existing theories and drug-based experiments. I also connect theories on the effects and principles of language to propose new theories and develop simulation models, thereby enriching the research.

    To achieve these goals, I combine: (1) knowledge from the history of cybernetics and philosophy of mind; (2) mathematical data analysis methods using probabilistic inference and graph theory; (3) modeling with statistical mechanics and complex systems physics; (4) applications of reinforcement learning, world models, and robotics.

    In conclusion, my research aims to bridge the gap between theoretical principles and practical applications, providing a comprehensive understanding of complex phenomena and contributing to the advancement of intelligent machine design.
